item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Exploring the Fun Side of China’s War on Corruption
item.description: A growing comedic collection suggests that the Chinese have realized that President Xi Jinping’s effort to curb graft is no passing fad, and that they might as well have some fun with it.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wang Qishan, who heads the Communist Party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, responsible for rooting out corruption, has figured as a character in Chinese jokes.

item.title: Terrorism Case Renews Debate Over Drone Hits
item.description: An American citizen who was once considered a possible target to be killed in Pakistan is now in custody in the United States, bolstering an argument that it is feasible to capture terrorism suspects, even in remote parts of the world.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Marshals at the courthouse where an American citizen was charged with supporting terrorism.

item.title: Memo From Panama: Talks With Cuba Earn U.S. Raves in Latin America
item.description: The question now is whether President Obama and his successors can capitalize on the new credibility Washington has earned, primarily through his rapprochement with Havana.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama’s talk with President Raúl Castro of Cuba drew praise from Latin American leaders and an editorial in El Universal with the headline “A New Era in the Americas.”

item.title: Saudi Spurns Call by Iran to Draw Back From Yemen
item.description: The foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, accused Tehran of meddling, as a feud between two regional powers intensified.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Pattern of Safety Lapses Where Group Worked to Battle Ebola Outbreak
item.description: Safety deficiencies at a treatment center staffed by Partners in Health, a charity that pledged to fight Ebola in Sierra Leone and Liberia, led to the closure of the center after two clinicians were diagnosed with Ebola.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: Sinai Group Kills Officers in Bombings
item.description: Egyptian militants with ties to the Islamic State group killed at least 12 people in the northern Sinai Peninsula on Sunday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Brazilian Protests Return as Scandals Intensify
item.description: For the second time in a month, thousands of protesters marched in cities across Brazil calling for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in Rio de Janeiro to oppose President Dilma Rousseff, who has a 13 percent approval rating.

item.title: Global Manager: At the Moulin Rouge, It’s All in the Family
item.description: An interview with the president and chief executive of the Moulin Rouge in Paris, Jean-Jacques Clérico.
item.dc:creator: SONIA KOLESNIKOV-JESSOP

item.title: Turmoil Between Political Leaders Has Harmed Bangladesh’s People
item.description: The battle of “the two ladies,” Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and the opposition leader Khaleda Zia, has led to more than 100 deaths and has hurt the crucial garment industry.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Pope Calls Killings of Armenians ‘Genocide,’ Provoking Turkish Anger
item.description: In speaking of the World War I-era slaughter of Armenians, the pontiff upset officials in Turkey, which has resisted the genocide designation, saying that a large number of Turks were also killed during that period.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Pope Francis on Sunday during a Mass on the 100th anniversary of the start of the killings of an estimated 1.5 million Armenians.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Father-Daughter War
item.description: Jean-Marie Le Pen is striking back. Could this bury Marine Le Pen's dream of one day reaching France's presidential palace?
item.dc:creator: ALAN RIDING
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, left, and Jean-Marie Le Pen at a National Front event in 2014.

item.title: Formal Charges May Be Next in Europe’s Google Antitrust Inquiry
item.description: Margrethe Vestager, Europe’s antitrust regulator, is expected to change course with her predecessor and file charges that could hasten a settlement.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and CONOR DOUGHERTY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Yemen’s President: The Houthis Must Be Stopped
item.description: My country is besieged by pro-Iranian militias. It is in no nation's interest to let them win.
item.dc:creator: ABDU RABBU MANSOUR HADI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The End of the Rainbow Nation Myth
item.description: Chris Hani was assassinated 22 years ago, but a new generation of South Africans is embracing his radical restlessness.
item.dc:creator: SISONKE MSIMANG

item.title: Pope Calls Killings of Armenians ‘Genocide,’ Provoking Turkish Anger
item.description: In speaking of the World War I-era slaughter of Armenians, the pontiff upset officials in Turkey, which has argued that a large number of Turks were also killed during that period.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Emails Reveal Discord Over Blackwater Charges
item.description: The disagreement foreshadowed an argument that will play out in court on Monday, when four former security contractors are scheduled to be sentenced over a deadly shooting in Iraq in 2007.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: The former Blackwater security guards, from left: Paul A. Slough, Dustin L. Heard, Nicholas A. Slatten and Evan S. Liberty.

item.title: 2 Killed in Shooting at South Korean Embassy in Libya
item.description: The Tripoli chapter of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in which gunmen killed two local police officers guarding the mission.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Steps Up Bombing Raids in Anbar After Shiite Militias Withdraw
item.description: The American ambassador to Iraq had expressed his dissatisfaction that Shiite militiamen were in the thick of a local offensive against Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and FALIH HASSAN

item.title: Political Economy: A British Tax Break in Need of Fine-Tuning
item.description: Britain's so-called non-dom system gives some rich people what appears to be an unfair tax break, but abolishing it could cost the country.
item.dc:creator: HUGO DIXON | REUTERS

item.title: From A to Z (Asteroids to Zombies), the British Just Want the Facts
item.description: A decade ago, the doors were swung wide open to allow public scrutiny into agencies, bureaus and councils, and the result has been both gratifying and slightly alarming.
item.dc:creator: BRYONY CLARKE
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lord David Clark of Windermere, the cabinet minister in the government of Tony Blair who drafted the Freedom of Information bill, said the law was long overdue and a success.
